user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimedWrite:
```c
int32 OS_TimedWrite(osal_id_t filedes, const void *buffer, size_t nbytes, int32 timeout)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(nbytes);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_GenericWrite_Impl(&token, buffer, nbytes, timeout);
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimedWrite:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_GenericWrite_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *buffer, size_t nbytes, int32 timeout)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    ssize_t                         os_result;
    uint32                          operation;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    if (nbytes > 0)
    {
        operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;

        /*
         * If filehandle is set with O_NONBLOCK, then must call select() here.
         *
         * The "selectable" field should be set false for those file handles
         * which the underlying OS does not support select() on.
         *
         * Note that a timeout will not work unless selectable is true.
         */
        if (impl->selectable)
        {
            return_code = OS_SelectSingle_Impl(token, &operation, timeout);
        }

        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS && (operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE) != 0)
        {
            /* on some system libraries for which the write() argument is not
             * qualified correctly, it needs to be case to a void* here */
            os_result = write(impl->fd, GENERIC_IO_CONST_DATA_CAST buffer, nbytes);
            if (os_result < 0)
            {
                OS_DEBUG("write: %s\n", strerror(errno));
                return_code = OS_ERROR;
            }
            else
            {
                /* type conversion from ssize_t to int32 for return */
                return_code = (int32)os_result;
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected the macros and transaction/abort-related routines because they are the constructs most likely to introduce non-returning behavior (or conditional non-returning behavior) that can create unreachable code elsewhere. Specifically:

- The OS_CHECK_POINTER and OS_CHECK_SIZE macros expand to BUGCHECK/ARGCHECK invocations. Depending on the definitions of BUGCHECK/ARGCHECK (not provided) these may call an assert/abort routine or otherwise not return. If they do not return in some configurations, code following them in the same function can become effectively unreachable and must be investigated.

- UtAssert_Abort (and the underlying UT_BSP_DoText call it makes) appears to represent an abort assertion. If UtAssert_Abort or UT_BSP_DoText do not return (or may longjmp), that affects reachability and must be checked.

- The OS_ObjectIdTransaction* functions (Init, Cancel, Finish) are transaction/locking helpers. Their semantics may include aborts or non-returning error handling in some builds; if so, they can render subsequent code unreachable. The invocation of OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit in OS_ObjectIdGetById and the calls to OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel/Finish should be inspected to confirm they behave as normal returning functions.

All other code fragments in the provided functions appear to be normal conditional control flow (ifs, returns) and do not, from the provided sources, contain statements that are statically unreachable (e.g., code after an unconditional return within the same function, duplicated mutually-exclusive branches, or unreachable switch labels). Therefore they do not need investigation for Rule 2.1 based on the supplied code. If additional definitions (e.g., BUGCHECK, ARGCHECK, UT_BSP_DoText, or the transaction routines) reveal non-returning behavior, further analysis of the call sites listed above will be necessary.
